Biomaterials_Dataset.Implant_Category: Load-bearing orthopaedic; spinal; trauma

Biocompatibility_Profile.Osseointegration_Potential: High - forms stable TiO2 oxide layer enabling direct bone apposition; used in load-bearing femoral stems and acetabular cups
Biocompatibility_Profile.Corrosion_Resistance: Excellent - passive TiO2 oxide film; corrosion rate < 0.01 mm/year in simulated body fluid
Biocompatibility_Profile.Toxicity_Risks: None clinically significant at bulk material level; trace vanadium ion release at nano-scale debated but ELI grade significantly mitigates risk

Biomaterials_Dataset.Implant_Category: Load-bearing orthopaedic; dental; cardiovascular

Biocompatibility_Profile.Osseointegration_Potential: Medium - bioinert; bone attachment is mechanical via surface roughness rather than chemical bonding; used effectively in hip/knee articulating surfaces
Biocompatibility_Profile.Corrosion_Resistance: Excellent - Cr2O3 passive film formed; minor Co, Cr, Mo ion release in vivo reported
Biocompatibility_Profile.Toxicity_Risks: Metal ion hypersensitivity possible (Cobalt, Chromium, Nickel); metal-on-metal articulation generates nano-particles linked to adverse local tissue reactions (ALTR)

Biomaterials_Dataset.Implant_Category: Spinal interbody fusion; craniomaxillofacial; radiolucent orthopaedic

Biocompatibility_Profile.Osseointegration_Potential: Low (unmodified) - bioinert polymer; no cytotoxicity, genotoxicity, or immunogenicity confirmed over 20+ years of clinical data; HA-coated or plasma-treated PEEK achieves Medium
Biocompatibility_Profile.Corrosion_Resistance: Excellent - chemically inert polymer; not susceptible to electrochemical corrosion
Biocompatibility_Profile.Toxicity_Risks: None clinically significant; radiolucent enabling post-op MRI/CT imaging without artifact

Biomaterials_Dataset.Implant_Category: Trauma fixation; fracture plates; temporary orthopaedic hardware

Biocompatibility_Profile.Osseointegration_Potential: Low - not designed for permanent osseous integration; used for temporary fixation hardware removed after healing
Biocompatibility_Profile.Corrosion_Resistance: Good - Cr2O3 passive layer; susceptibility to pitting and crevice corrosion in chloride-rich physiological fluids under fretting conditions
Biocompatibility_Profile.Toxicity_Risks: Nickel ion release can cause hypersensitivity reactions in susceptible patients; not recommended for permanent long-term implantation

Biomaterials_Dataset.Implant_Category: Bone substitute; coating for metallic implants; non-load-bearing defect filling

Biocompatibility_Profile.Osseointegration_Potential: High - chemically identical to bone mineral phase; strongly osteoconductive; direct chemical bonding with living bone demonstrated in vivo
Biocompatibility_Profile.Corrosion_Resistance: Excellent - ceramic; chemically stable in physiological pH; slow resorption (non-resorbable to very slowly resorbable)
Biocompatibility_Profile.Toxicity_Risks: None clinically significant; potential osteolysis if exposed to bone marrow and soft tissues noted in some reports

Biomaterials_Dataset.Implant_Category: Articular bearing surface (hip, knee, shoulder joint replacement)

Biocompatibility_Profile.Osseointegration_Potential: Low - polymer bearing surface not intended for osseous integration; functions via mechanical interlock of fixation component
Biocompatibility_Profile.Corrosion_Resistance: Excellent - chemically inert polymer; no electrochemical degradation
Biocompatibility_Profile.Toxicity_Risks: Wear debris particles trigger macrophage response, aseptic loosening, and osteolysis; highly cross-linked UHMWPE variants significantly reduce wear particle generation

Biomaterials_Dataset.Implant_Category: Bone defect regeneration; bioactive scaffold; non-load-bearing dental/maxillofacial

Biocompatibility_Profile.Osseointegration_Potential: High - bioactive; rapidly forms carbonated hydroxyapatite (CHA) layer on surface within hours of implantation; documented direct bonding to both hard and soft tissue
Biocompatibility_Profile.Corrosion_Resistance: Not applicable (bioactive; controlled dissolution is the functional mechanism; degrades within 9-12 months in vivo)
Biocompatibility_Profile.Toxicity_Risks: None clinically significant; no cytotoxicity or chronic inflammation observed in in vivo studies

Biomaterials_Dataset.Implant_Category: Biodegradable orthopaedic (bone screws, cardiovascular stents)

Biocompatibility_Profile.Osseointegration_Potential: Medium - osteoconductive and biocompatible; bone forms around degrading implant; complete replacement of implant by bone tissue is the intended outcome
Biocompatibility_Profile.Corrosion_Resistance: Moderate - lower initial corrosion rate vs. other Mg alloys; SLM-produced in vitro corrosion rate 1.3-2.6 mm/year; rare earth elements improve protective oxide layer
Biocompatibility_Profile.Toxicity_Risks: Hydrogen gas evolution during rapid corrosion; biological effects of yttrium (Y) and rare earth (RE) elements remain under investigation; degradation generates local alkalinity

Biomaterials_Dataset.Implant_Category: Biodegradable orthopaedic (load-bearing bone plates, fracture fixation)

Biocompatibility_Profile.Osseointegration_Potential: Medium - promotes new bone formation; AZ31B noted to be biocompatible and biodegradable in vivo models
Biocompatibility_Profile.Corrosion_Resistance: Moderate to Poor - in vitro corrosion rate up to 0.91 mm/year in DMEM; mechanical properties degrade significantly with corrosion (tensile strength drops from ~252 MPa to ~73 MPa at 3 months in vitro)
Biocompatibility_Profile.Toxicity_Risks: Aluminum (Al) ion release is a concern for long-term neurotoxicity at high concentrations; rapid degradation may cause local tissue irritation from pH rise and H2 evolution

Biomaterials_Dataset.Implant_Category: Dental implants; femoral heads; maxillofacial

Biocompatibility_Profile.Osseointegration_Potential: Medium - biologically inert; cell proliferation rates comparable to control; lacks bioactivity for direct chemical bonding but surface modifications can improve osseointegration; limits bacterial proliferation
Biocompatibility_Profile.Corrosion_Resistance: Excellent - chemically inert ceramic; no electrochemical degradation in physiological fluids
Biocompatibility_Profile.Toxicity_Risks: None clinically significant; potential low-temperature degradation (LTD) / hydrothermal aging in humid environment can compromise mechanical stability over time

Biomaterials_Dataset.Implant_Category: Dental implants; endosseous fixtures; maxillofacial hardware

Biocompatibility_Profile.Osseointegration_Potential: High - gold standard for dental osseointegration; >95% 10-year survival rates documented clinically; forms stable TiO2 layer; no alloying elements minimizes allergy risk
Biocompatibility_Profile.Corrosion_Resistance: Excellent - spontaneous TiO2 passivation; very low corrosion rate in physiological environments
Biocompatibility_Profile.Toxicity_Risks: None clinically significant; absence of alloying elements (Al, V) eliminates related cytotoxicity concerns

Biomaterials_Dataset.Implant_Category: Cardiovascular stents; guidewires; orthodontic archwires; bone staples

Biocompatibility_Profile.Osseointegration_Potential: Low - not applicable for primary use; stent/wire function relies on shape memory/superelasticity; surface passivation forms TiO2-rich layer limiting Ni release
Biocompatibility_Profile.Corrosion_Resistance: Good - surface TiO2 passivation layer provides corrosion protection; Ni release decreases significantly post-passivation treatment
Biocompatibility_Profile.Toxicity_Risks: Nickel content (55-56 wt%) presents risk for Ni hypersensitivity; long-term in vivo Ni ion release is a clinical concern; surface oxide passivation treatments are critical to minimizing risk

Biomaterials_Dataset.Implant_Category: Bio-absorbable; drug delivery; soft tissue scaffold; bioabsorbable sutures

Biocompatibility_Profile.Osseointegration_Potential: Low (unmodified) - bioresorbable polymer matrix; poor osteoconductivity in pure form; used as scaffold/carrier material rather than bone-bonding implant
Biocompatibility_Profile.Corrosion_Resistance: Not applicable (biodegradable by hydrolysis of ester linkages; degradation products are lactic acid and glycolic acid, both metabolized via Krebs cycle)
Biocompatibility_Profile.Toxicity_Risks: FDA-approved for biomedical use; degradation may cause local acidification; historical PLGA suture anchors associated with rare cyst formation and sterile inflammation in some cases

Biomaterials_Dataset.Implant_Category: Revision joint arthroplasty; spinal fusion; bone defect reconstruction

Biocompatibility_Profile.Osseointegration_Potential: High - highly porous structure (up to 75-80% porosity) mimics cancellous bone; extensive vascular and osseous ingrowth; osteoconductive, osteoinductive, and angioinductive properties
Biocompatibility_Profile.Corrosion_Resistance: Excellent - rapid Ta2O5 passivation; highly resistant to physiological acidic and alkaline environments
Biocompatibility_Profile.Toxicity_Risks: None clinically significant; minimal ion release; excellent biocompatibility demonstrated in FDA-cleared devices

Biomaterials_Dataset.Implant_Category: Spinal fusion cages; orthopaedic load-bearing ceramics

Biocompatibility_Profile.Osseointegration_Potential: High - bioactive; promotes osteogenesis and osteodifferentiation; 90.2% fusion success rate in multicenter clinical study; active suppression of osteoclasts observed
Biocompatibility_Profile.Corrosion_Resistance: Excellent - chemically stable; forms surface silanol groups that interact beneficially with biological environment
Biocompatibility_Profile.Toxicity_Risks: None clinically significant; in vivo and in vitro studies confirm non-toxicity; inherent antibacterial properties demonstrated against multiple pathogen species via ammonia ion elution mechanism

Biomaterials_Dataset.Implant_Category: Load-bearing orthopaedic; cementless femoral hip stems; maxillofacial

Biocompatibility_Profile.Osseointegration_Potential: High - Nb replaces V eliminating vanadium cytotoxicity; promotes osseointegration comparable to Ti-6Al-4V ELI; in clinical use since 1986 for hip prostheses
Biocompatibility_Profile.Corrosion_Resistance: Excellent - stable passive oxide film in physiological environments; prevents metal ion release
Biocompatibility_Profile.Toxicity_Risks: None clinically significant; developed explicitly to eliminate vanadium-related toxicity; niobium considered biologically safe at implant-level ion concentrations

Biomaterials_Dataset.Implant_Category: Total hip arthroplasty femoral heads/acetabular liners; dental crowns; hard-on-hard bearing surfaces

Biocompatibility_Profile.Osseointegration_Potential: Low - bioinert ceramic; stable at bone-implant interface but relies on press-fit mechanical fixation; no chemical bonding to bone
Biocompatibility_Profile.Corrosion_Resistance: Excellent - highly chemically inert; stable in all physiological environments; ISO 10993-1 compliant per in vitro and in vivo studies
Biocompatibility_Profile.Toxicity_Risks: None clinically significant; inherent brittleness (fracture toughness 3.4-4.6 MPa·m^0.5) limits use in high-impact applications; risk of catastrophic fracture under extreme cyclic loading

Biomaterials_Dataset.Implant_Category: Bio-absorbable orthopaedic (interference screws, suture anchors, pins); craniofacial fixation

Biocompatibility_Profile.Osseointegration_Potential: Low (unmodified) - biocompatible but bioresorbable; not designed for osseointegration; complete in vivo degradation 36-60 months via hydrolysis; no inflammatory response or osteoclast activity at screw sites in minipig studies up to 3 years
Biocompatibility_Profile.Corrosion_Resistance: Not applicable (biodegradable; degrades by hydrolysis into L-lactic acid, metabolized via Krebs cycle to CO2 + H2O)
Biocompatibility_Profile.Toxicity_Risks: Generally biocompatible; highly crystalline PLLA can accumulate particulates if degradation rate outpaces phagocytic clearance; foreign body granuloma reported in rare cases

Biomaterials_Dataset.Material_Name: CoCrW Alloy (ASTM F90, Wrought - UNS R30605)
Biomaterials_Dataset.Implant_Category: Cardiovascular stents; vascular clips; surgical wire

Biocompatibility_Profile.Osseointegration_Potential: Low - not designed for osseointegration; stent/wire applications require endothelialization rather than bone integration
Biocompatibility_Profile.Corrosion_Resistance: Excellent - Cr2O3 passive layer; high resistance to corrosion in physiological fluids; wrought processing improves homogeneity vs. cast
Biocompatibility_Profile.Toxicity_Risks: Nickel content (9-11 wt%) presents hypersensitivity risk; Co, Cr, W ion release possible under fretting; metal ion monitoring recommended for long-term vascular implants

Biomaterials_Dataset.Implant_Category: Resorbable bone graft substitute; dental bone augmentation; craniofacial defect filling

Biocompatibility_Profile.Osseointegration_Potential: High - highly osteoconductive; actively resorbed by osteoclasts and replaced by new bone; resorption rate matched to bone regeneration at 6-24 months depending on porosity
Biocompatibility_Profile.Corrosion_Resistance: Not applicable (intentionally resorbable by osteoclastic resorption and chemical dissolution in physiological fluids)
Biocompatibility_Profile.Toxicity_Risks: None clinically significant; degradation products (Ca2+, PO4^3-) are normal physiological ions; FDA-cleared for dental and orthopaedic applications

Biomaterials_Dataset.Material_Name: Commercially Pure Titanium Grade 2 (CP-Ti Grade 2, ASTM F67)
Biomaterials_Dataset.Implant_Category: Dental implant components; pacemaker housings; maxillofacial mesh

Biocompatibility_Profile.Osseointegration_Potential: High - highly biocompatible; osseointegration well established over 50+ years of clinical use (Brånemark protocol); spontaneous TiO2 layer enables direct bone contact
Biocompatibility_Profile.Corrosion_Resistance: Excellent - passive TiO2 self-healing oxide layer; corrosion resistant in chloride and protein-rich environments of implant sites
Biocompatibility_Profile.Toxicity_Risks: None clinically significant; one of the most biocompatible metals; suitable for patients with metal sensitivities due to absence of Ni, Co, V alloying elements

Biomaterials_Dataset.Implant_Category: Total hip arthroplasty hard bearing couples (femoral head / acetabular liner); high-wear-resistance articulating surfaces

Biocompatibility_Profile.Osseointegration_Potential: Low - bioinert composite ceramic; no chemical bonding to bone; mechanical fixation via press-fit or cement
Biocompatibility_Profile.Corrosion_Resistance: Excellent - chemically inert composite; no electrochemical corrosion; ZrO2 addition reduces LTD (low-temperature degradation) vs. pure alumina
Biocompatibility_Profile.Toxicity_Risks: None clinically significant; fracture toughness 10+ MPa·m^0.5 significantly superior to monolithic alumina, reducing catastrophic fracture risk; ISO 6474-2 governed

Alumina and Zirconia Ceramics in Major Orthopaedic Applications

Beta tricalcium phosphate (β-TCP): A biomaterial in restorative dentistry - A review
